title: Mixed response to proposed health and safety reforms
text:
Sat, Jul 25, 2015, 5:45 PM NZST - New Zealand Markets closed Mixed response to proposed health and safety reforms By Jacqui Stanford | Newstalk ZB – 6 hours ago Recommend Print 
There has been a mixed response to proposed health and safety reforms. 
A select committee has reported back on the Health and Safety Reform Bill, which overhauled health and safety rules in the wake of the disaster in which 29 workers on the West Coast died in 2010. 
The proposals include removing the requirements to have health and safety representatives in smaller low-risk workplaces who employ fewer than 20 people. 
Business New Zealand's Phil O'Reilly believes the new legislation has been drafted from a sound base and has been further improved by responding to issues raised by business. 
"The trick will be to make sure that those changes play out in a sensible way for business, and a lot of that will be about the way that the Worksafe authority itself puts those changes in place and polices them and helps businesses comply with them." 
But Council of Trade Unions President Helen Kelly says it means thousands of workers in small businesses will lose a whole lot of rights. 
"For example of you don't have a workplace rep, which you won't have to have in a small business, there's nobody in the workplace that can cease dangerous work or accompany health and safety inspections, a whole range of things which will now be denied." 
Ms Kelly says the government has become opportunist, instead of honouring those who died at Pike River. 
"Instead of honouring those men, changing the law and protecting people, they're actually using that disaster, pretending they're doing something and using it as an excuse to water down the health and safety law." @YahooNZBusiness on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Pilbara miner seeks return to trade AAP
